ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a ton about the history of nuclear energy as well as how to read primary sources and develop an opinion on a complicated topic.

I gained a greater understanding of the cultural construction of the concept of wilderness and how the American conception of wilderness has influenced the activity of the nuclear industry in the United States. The course greatly altered my own perspectives surrounding the American landscape and wilderness as a whole.

I learned an in-depth knowledge of how concepts of wilderness and landscape are largely influenced by the U.S. nuclear industrial complex and the development of nuclear weapons and testing in North America.

I felt that I really strengthened my skills in visual analysis because we spent a lot of time engaging with photographs of nuclear landscapes. I also developed my skills in different kinds of writing, such as writing exhibition labels and op-eds, in addition to more formal academic papers. Crucially, I learned so much I didn't know/hadn't been taught about America's use of nuclear power and weapons in its colonial and imperial projects.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course subject was extremely interesting and the creativity of the assignments allowed for better exploration of the subject.

The curriculum was extremely engaging and lots of the material relate to our modern day. At times, the course was not the most engaging and I found myself uninterested in the way the content was being taught.

Strengths: Definitely Charlotte! She was super knowledgeable, helpful, and kind. She curated a list of very interesting readings for us each week, and she was great at moderating our class discussions. I appreciated that she incorporated diverse ways for us to discuss our readings, including small groups and by writing key themes/terms in concept maps on the chalkboards. The field trips were also awesome!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! Its endowed, so whoever is teaching has money to supplement the classroom experience with field trips and such, which makes it a much more engaging and immersive experience.
I would absolutely recommend this course, and I have, to any student who will listen. The course was extremely engaging with many unique opportunities to participate in and outside of class time.
Yes, the content we learn is extremely informative to many of the issues we see in the environment.

Yes! Charlotte is a fantastic instructor, and you learn about very important facets of America's history and current events through very interesting readings and engaging field trips. The workload is also very reasonable, so this won't be a class that stresses you out.
